dt: {bc}feeling or showing great affection and devotion

dt.t: He was twenty then, an only son, spoiled by his {wi}adoring{/wi} family.

utxt.t: He had accused her of not taking him seriously, and she had replied … that she took him religiously, {wi}adoringly{/wi}.

shortdef: feeling or showing great affection and devotion

dt: {bc}to worship or honor as a deity or as divine
{bc}to regard with loving admiration and devotion

pt: {sc}revere{/sc} {sc}reverence{/sc} {sc}venerate{/sc} {sc}worship{/sc} {sc}adore{/sc} mean to honor and admire profoundly and respectfully. {sc}revere{/sc} stresses deference and tenderness of feeling.
{sc}reverence{/sc} presupposes an intrinsic merit and inviolability in the one honored and a similar depth of feeling in the one honoring.
{sc}venerate{/sc} implies a holding as holy or sacrosanct because of character, association, or age.
{sc}worship{/sc} implies homage usually expressed in words or ceremony.
{sc}adore{/sc} implies love and stresses the notion of an individual and personal attachment.

et: Middle English {it}aouren, adouren,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}aurer, ahourer, adourer{/it} (with {it}d{/it} restored from Latin), going back to Latin {it}adōrāre{/it} "to plead with, appeal to, approach (a god) as a suppliant or worshipper, treat with reverence, admire," from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}ōrāre{/it} "to pray to, beseech" {ma}{mat|oration|}{/ma}
shortdef: to worship or honor as a deity or as divine
to regard with loving admiration and devotion
